Water looks terrible, no 3d grass for light rough and rough, lighting is very basic and the performance is inconsistant from course to course. I have to turn settings down on an I7 4790k@4.6ghz and a amd Fury to maintain 60fps on some courses.Gameplay - 7/10 RTS is broken, it is way too sensitive, move the mouse back 2 pixels and thats a full back swing at 800dpi* on a 1080p screen, only increasing the screen to 1440p and the mouse DPI down to 400 is the RTS some what controlable,this is using the lowest sensitivity setting in game....Even then there is no feel and putting is a joke, with the ball rocketing off the face after the smallest slowest movement you can possibly do with a mouse, to top this the game gives zero feedback whilst on the course has to what you are doing right or wrong, the only way to get feedback is to go to the practice area (no putting green btw), and you will get feedback through a launch monitor,  not that it will be any use to you as there is zero explination of what the numbers mean, so if you have never been on launch monitor in real life and had the number explained to you, you are screwed basically. This wasn't thought through at all and they listened to totally the wrong people when implementing this.*Mice used Roccat Kone XTD and Corsair Vengence M65However mouse swing using the meter isn't bad at all,  although it will be very difficult for the beginner. so max assists is recommended..Presention - 6/10 simple menus very easy to navigate....nothing to write home about Value - 5/10 Thought long and hard about this, if the game was £14.99 i would say yes the game is good value for what you get, but they have released it at £26.99...and on top of that have release an extra course as day one DLC (if you have DLC ready for day one, it should be in the game at no extra cost) and are planning more micro transactions.  So id say this game isn't good value, as of now there is no career or progression system, there is a planned course designer, but has yet to materialise (no idea what its going to be like)...there is online play, and solo rounds, for a golf enthusiast maybe just enough, but for a gamer looking for something to play, £26.99 is going to be poor value.Overall 5/10 This game offers nothing for the causual/gamer player, the learning curve is very steep, with zero understandable feedback from the game ( A launch monitor is jibberish to the none enthusiast Golfer, even to some Serious golfers), The gameplay is kind of there, you just have to put is stupid amounts of hours to find it, and you will have to go on the forums to find out what the numbers on launch monitor mean....I do like parts of this game, but i can not recommend it (not at £26.99), so its a thumbs down from me.Edit... I was banned from the forums for critizing thier micro transactions implementation in this game, the game is on its way to pay to win, with being able to buy balls and clubs that change the way the game plays.....Avoid this game and do not support this GREEDY developer.Edit... I just found out that this developer is going to make you pay for "major" updates to the game, disguising them as DLC....So this means if you want to keep your game upto date you are going to have to keep sheling out your hard earned cash to do so, and this is after they have the nerve to charge £26.99 for a half finished game.....Edit... This is a quote from the Dev reguarding the future of the game"Once additional Feature driven DLC is available access to play user created content will be limited to those players who are on the new version." This means courses you create yourself you will not be able to play anymore once the DLC update is released unless you buy it....This is disgusting from the dev its not enough that you have already paid for the game, they just want to fleece you out of more money.....Devs if you read this, its not the peoples who bought this games fault you underestemated how much this game would cost to develop and its not right to ask them to pay extra for updates, no matter how substantial the update is, The way good developers work is once you buy a licence for a game or piece of software it entitles you to updates for life, unless specifically stated...This was not the case with this game, you waited until we had paid our money, and then unleased the news that we would have to pay money for "milestone" updates....Sorry but this is morally repugnant on your part, and you have shown that you are just going to milk this community for a long time to come...i really hope more people see through you.Shame really because your game isn't bad, and if you had used directx11 from the start (oh one of things they want to charge for is porting the game to DX12)  and polished the game a little more before releasing it, the game would have sold well and you wouldn't have had to resort to such shaddy practices.

												The entire Bug Reporting section of the Perfect Parallel forums, is not even available to the public. A user must register in order to view the Bug Reporting section of the Perfect Parallel forums. Here, try to find it, otherwise: http://www.perfectparallel.com/forum/26-perfect-golf-bug-reporting/ Instead of taking bug reports seriously, the developers have religiously deleted legitimate forum posts, and fabricated TOS violations out of whole cloth... in an obvious attempt to muzzle legitimate criticisms.When a developer starts deleting on-topic forum posts, devoid of any rules violations, whatsoever... than, they have reached a new low. The developer has now fully retaliated against these criticisms... by issuing a permanent forum ban; as of December, 19, 2015.Only, that's not the good part. The good part; is that, the developer actually dredged up a forum post from May, 2015... as a pretext for a permanent forum ban, that has now been issued over 6 months later! So, basically... Necroban. Here's the screenshot to prove the surreptitious hilarity. If you'll notice, there isn't even anything listed under the all important, "Ban Reason." http://s19.postimg.org/3tdzlgav7/2015_12_19_pg_forum_ban.pngThe fact that, a game developer, would actually peruse back over 6 months into a user's post history, as a pretext, to ban them from the forums - and still not be able to come up with a legitimate reason - is both sad, and pathetic... on so many levels. (The ban has since been revoked)Forget about the game. One would reasonably expect more professional behavior from the developers.Nevertheless, here are the rest of the issues with this game:While there are multiple control methods; the controls – particularly when attempting to navigate through the menus and the settings - are both clunky and frustrating.There exists no tutorial, despite the entire piece of software being anything but user-friendly.While there does exist an official Practice Facility, the player is not able to move around, nor follow any shot within said facility; nor can the player putt in the practice facility.The sound is somewhat intermittent, with the impact of golf shots oftentimes being completely missed.The graphics are not entirely terrible, if one is able to use their own imagination... with several obvious gaffes, relating to blending, or the lack thereof; as well as, poor water reflections, and nonexistent edge refraction.For example, the outline of the rough - that separates different types of rough - often bulges, and causes shots hit there to bump squarely up against the outline of the rough, as if the golf ball were coming in contact with a street curb, as opposed to - thick grass.Another example; is that the cart paths hover above the ground. The developer has stated this is intended, as it is apparently a workaround to another issue. – Okay.Another huge issue is the lack of smooth undulating surfaces, particularly on greens. There are jagged creases and geometric shapes with straight lines protruding from the ground; oftentimes causing the golf ball to veer off of its intended path, unnaturally.The latest golfer avatar looks horrendous. The setup positions are largely incorrect, down to the backwards hand positioning. Also, the swing animation has a terrible hitch in it. – It's all just very amateurish in appearance.There is no user customization, whatsoever. Each and every user is required to use the exact same character. The only variation being, some pewter-like shirt color adjustments.The developers have repeatedly made unproven claims about the accuracy of their physics engine, as it relates to actual Tour Golf... despite the actual in-game physics being routinely over-corrected, with each subsequent new draft version of this game.Hitting three-quarter shots makes the ball roll forward excessively, moreso than would be realistically attainable with any given club.In this game; shorter, more-lofted clubs, will oftentimes actually incur more roll-out, than longer, less-lofted clubs... when struck in the same exact manner. Go figure that one out.Or, shots struck with more power, right on the sweet spot, will oftentimes inexplicably lose distance... regardless of the trajectory of the shot.Occasionally, the golf ball will actually penetrate underneath the surface of the turf, warp underground, and pop back up above the surface. This is completely inexplicable, and destroys all immersion.There have been ongoing issues with ball markers; not showing up, nor being in their correct location.There have been ongoing issues with Gimmes; freezing the game progression entirely... when hitting a par 3 tee shot that lands inside Gimme range.The Concede Hole button oftentimes causes the wrong player or team to win the hole.There have been ongoing issues with multiplayer connectivity failing.There have been ongoing connection issues, which may cause undue stuttering while spectating shots.There are ongoing issues with lag, and unexplained disconnections.The Course Creator has yet to be released. However, some beta testers have managed to create courses. The issue is that the system is entirely disorganized, causing users to have to download each course from varying download services, and manually extract each file individually into the correct game directory. There are also no Auto-Updates in place, which also can cause users to have different versions of courses. Yet, there are also false positives, that prevent users from joining games, when the two users in question actually do have the same course version.The lobby itself, is setup rather haphazardly, with inaccurate and incomplete references to player locations.The game is constantly being pirated, and the developers cannot seem to figure out how to kick multiples of obviously hijacked Steam accounts, from the lobby. Chat boxes oftentimes fail, rendering in-game communication inoperable. Also, Multiplayer games are not automatically setup for Voice Chat. Players have to either setup Steam Voice Chat, on their own; or use utilize an outside Voice Chat service.There is no Shot-Clock to dictate a fair pace of play, which is part of the official rules of golf. Since there is no Simultaneous play option in this software... the lack of a Shot-Clock becomes a big deal, as multiplayer stroke games tend to run quite long; or at least, much longer than they conceivably should.It is not possible to convert a grouping to Custom difficulty settings. The difficulty settings chosen must fall under a default difficulty level. The alternative is to allow “Any” difficulty level to join the game; which creates obvious mismatches.The putter head is not at any time squared up at address. Not only that, but the putting itself seems to impart far more break than would realistically occur on similar greens, in real life. One of the most egregious issues, is the lack of Competitive Purpose, anywhere in the game. There is no Career Mode. There is no Official Tour. There are no Rated Multiplayer Games. There are no Win/Loss Records. There are no Experience Points. There aren't even any In-Game Statistics, nor any track-able Player Averages.While anyone can play or join Multiplayer games with and against other users; there is presently nothing whatsoever to play for.“Perfect Golf,” is like a less polished version of the Tiger Woods Golf series. A Poor Man's Tiger Woods Golf, if you will. It originally showed some promise. But, as of yet, there are too many game-breaking bugs, ongoing... as well as, occasional physics anomalies, and the glaring lack of any Competitive Purpose, whatsoever; which would compel any fair-minded individual to - in its current state - give it a thumbs down.

For those of us who like a golf game with a real-time mouse swing buy this early access release and see if the improvements over time make it better. $20 isn't a deal breaker. However, the view is good, I have no tears or glitches and the screenshots I've taken look great. I can play the game at fullscreen in 1920 x 1080, so everything is as I expect. Gameplay is almost spot on. It puts you in total control when playing using the 3 click system. The other control method is still being developed, so I'd expect that area to improve alot over the coming months. I won't comment any more on that, as I've not really tested it. This isn't like older or other golf games, it feels more Sim than Arcade. Granted it has a few elements that are needed to transfer anything simulated to a computer game, but they are minimal and necessary. Real Time Weather is pretty cool, and works a treat. The Time of Day setting is one of my favourite things, being able to visually see the sun rising or setting, and playing a twilight game has the good old feel of those summer evenings, with time on your side.  Currently the 5 courses are just about right. With the promise of many more to come, it will soon become a tough decision choosing what course to entangle yourself within. Plus of course the Course Forge (Designer) a little further down the road.  I'd certainly like to see alot more improvements, walking the hole, first person perspective to name a basic few. However, reading the forums and discussions from the Dev's have made it clear these guys want to deliver something similar too. It feels like a winner to me.

								First off, a big thanks to the devs on bringing us this Early Access version of Perfect Golf. I'm running the game in windowed mode 1280x768 on a 5 year old laptop with AA on and Bloom on. Trees are set at 350, shadows 200, Grass 100 and camera view distance 1500. All things considered the game runs good apart from a few stutters here and there that I can live with and haven't yet affected the playability.Ball Physics: the team has done a wonderful job on the ball physics, especially after the latest update. I considered the ball physics in Links v1.07 to be one of the best I've seen in a golf game but in PG they've taken it to another level of realism. Sure, there is still some work to be done but having played a few different golf games this is the best I've experienced as yet .......BUT .... while I feel that tee to green the devs have created up to now the best simulation of real golf yet seen in a computer game, I do feel an element of realism is then lost with the putting model. To help explain this I should point out I am a novice real life golfer, having only played the game for around 18 months. So it is fresh in my mind what it is like to be a beginner and having to learn the game. I feel a simulation should have the same sort of difficulties and learning curve with all aids off as the real thing. That may also mean I'll never be able to shoot under par for a round as in real life. A par on a hole should feel like an achievement. Unfortunately the putting model destroys this sense of achievement because it feels like I have too much help. Sometimes I misjudge my long putts on a real course massively - and that never seems to happen to me in PG due to the putting meter. And sometimes in real life I've putted from the fairway just off the green and given too much power and ended up off the other side of the green. I can't seem to do that in PG as my power is limited by the meter.My suggestion - a straight swing bar that follows the movement of the mouse. The putter head placed two thirds down the bar with movement then for back swing and power and length of follow through for movement. Putting aids can be markings on the bar to help judge distance but true simulation mode with no aids would be with no markings and just from feel as in real golf. Don't know if something like this is possible. It would mean that by selecting a putter the graphic would automatically switch from an arcing swing meter to a straight putting bar. In simulation mode full back swing (of course restricted to a point) and full, fast follow through would always result in a maximum power putt.A free roam mode would be nice, even if it was only restricted to a 20 or 30 yard zone around the golfers position, to allow for better planning of shots like in real golf when views are restricted. Of course, these restricted views should also be set to golfers eye level for realism.Look forward to future update improvements and hopefully more courses. There is no option to change the swing meter speed to something of your liking. There is no option to add markers to the meter. The meter links to the graphics engine so if you don't have a silky smooth running game, you also won't have a silky smooth meter making it impossible to play. 												EDIT: Review changed in 9/16 to reflect a lack of progress in providing features that were supposed to be in the release. Specifically, the course designer for PG has been long discussed and was supposed to be in the game on release. 4 months later it's still not there. Beyond the course designer, there still is no career mode. The game still has performance issues. There still is limited character customization, no announcers, very limited stats, poor UI, etc. Essentially almost NONE of the negatives have been fixed even though many of those things have been promised. Thus I can't recommend the game because I don't see tangible progress in improving the product. -----I've been arounds since PG's failed kickstarter. I bought the game as soon as it came out on Early Access. However, that doesn't make me a fan. It makes me a fan of golf games. PG does some things right. It does some things wrong. Because it's a mixed bag, it's easier to list what is good and what's bad about it. As always, YMMV.Pros:- numerous swing type options - there are multiple though I'm a three clicker all the way and very impressed by the smoothness of the meter. The mouse swing is challenging. They've tried to implement no-cheating modes but they broke the mouse swing while doing so.- various levels of challenge - play this with all the aids on and you'll be in birdie city. Play this without them and you might be lucky to break 90. I'm not nearly as good as I once was, but at one point I was in the top 10 on Case's Ladder on Links and #1 on another ladder. So I'm glad it's challenging rather than the "Shoot 48 at Augusta on Tiger Woods" mode.- good physics - I'm still not happy with the backspin but generally the physics are good and better than any other golf game. Backspin still is off and I generate more backspin on my short irons (and I shoot in the 90s) than my avatar in this game. Other than that they're spot on. For instance, if you play a course at higher elevation the ball will travel further. That's a nice touch.- weather / time of day settings can add some real challenge to your game. I think the wind feels spot-on.- many different courses to choose from and quite a few to download- multiple modes of gameplay, including solo, multiplayer and tournaments with match play, team play, alt shot, etc.- no micro-transactions that improve your game- no stupid characters that drive the ball 400 yards. Over-driving distance ruins so many golf games and they've prevented that here.Cons:- no career mode built into the game yet- course designer hasn't been released yet (it's now 4 months late and counting)- I don't like the way the skies look and the trees can look a little jagged- limited current player animations (no lefties, no females yet though they're coming)- very,very, very limited character customization- it requires a decent computer and user made courses don't always run well. In fact, the user made courses often exceed the RAM allowance in the game causing major problems from a chunky swing meter to crashing.- slightly too limited shot shaping options. I wish I could position my swing path and feet differently to get inventive when shotmaking. - very limited stats- no announcer and limited sound effects- no Steam Workshop integration (a cardinal sin for a game with downloadable courses)- really poor and frankly butt-ugly user interface when you enter the game (though it's fine when actually playing a round)So it's up to you whether to buy it. I can tell you it's a better game than that "other" golf game on Steam and probably the best one available on the market today. But it's by no means perfect yet (pun intended) and while I had hoped that many of the cons would be fixed, this doesn't seem to be happening. The product feels more and more abandoned with a lack of substantial progress since release. If you want a golf game now, this is the one to buy becuase frankly it's probably your only decent choice. Since I'm a fan of the old Links games and golf games in general so I continue to load up PG from time to time. But if you aren't a golf nut, this game isn't for you because it's just too limited in the features and progress to appeal to a wider audience.

								Hands down the best golf simulation ever created. Things that seperates itself from other games:-A real time physics engine combined with real ball flight data(launch angles, spin rates and ball speeds) taken from launch monitors put this game in a class of it's own. Once you experience the before mentioned there really is no going back to other golf games.-The Motion Swing mouse mechanic is a first of it's kind that introduces D plane swing theory. What is D plane theory and how does it realate to the mouse? Well, the simplified answer is the tracking of the actual swing path plus the tracking of the clubface angle. Your swing path is determined by the direction you move the mouse and the clubface angle is determined by the tempo at which you move your mouse.-A real time weather and lighting system allow you to input a geographic location and play in those weather and lighting conditions. Never before has a golf game recreated weather and lighting conditions like this game. The lighting and shadow effects are exceptional and really change the look and feel of a course. You can even play in a thunder and lightning storm. Even though you wouldn't do this in real life it's worth doing in PG just to see the lightning effects.-The last thing worth mentioning, and maybe the most important is, this may be the first game to offer up realistic scores in competition. I see no way to shoot in the 50's on a consistent basis, especially with aids turned off. I see scores being very close to real life, maybe even higher. Since tempo plays such a high role in the swing, straight edging or trying to zero out the x axis on the mouse is not going to get your far. Also, since the game uses a real time physics engine to determine spin you can't put artificial spin on the ball and throw darts at every flag.$20 for this game is a steal. Buying it now will save you $10 to $15 when it goes retail. Once the course forge is released with the retail version and courses start pouring in, there will be no reason to even talk about another golf game. The potential this game has is limitless. If done right, this could be one of the greatest sports sims ever created.

								I have been playing Tiger Woods '08 PC on a regular basis since it came out back in 2007.  No modern golf game has come close.  That is until PerfectGolf was released.  The graphics are top notch and very realistic.  You can see all of the undulations and slopes on the fairways/greens very clearly unlike some golf games.  The addition of trees and bushes from SpeedTree last year improved the visuals a great deal. There are loads of different play modes available in PerfectGolf.  If tournaments are your thing you can participate in many online as well as ones on onlinegolftour.net. Your opponent(s) can see the replays as well.Another big plus for PerfectGolf is the freecam mode which allows you to more effectively read putts and scope out your next shot, even while your online opponent is getting ready to hit.  Take a virtual tour of the entire course from every conceivable angle and soak in the wonderful immersion that this game provides.PerfectGolf has lived up to its potential as superb golf simulation.  Every update over the last year has shown improvement, especially the most recent update from last month.  This community driven game will only get better in the months and years to come. Early Access Review
								I've been playing golf and computer games for about 25 years now, ever since I was about seven years old, so I feel reasonably qualified to comment on something that combines the two.The early access of Perfect Golf is a fantastic start and the devs appear to have every motivation to bring the game to full fruition. Unlike many early access titles, the devs at Perfect Golf aren't promising heaven and earth just to get people's money but they are promising to create a great golf sim for real golfers, something I firmly believe they are very capable of delivering.The current basic build is solid and enjoyable enough to hint at what is to come. Of course it has some bugs and it is missing many features and some areas require polish but these are all being identified and dealt with systematically and professionally as far as I can tell.For anyone looking to buy this game in its current form, note that it does not yet have the following features which some may want to wait for:- Computer opponents- Career mode- Golfer appearance customisation- Statistics and TrackingI would also say that, while the game looks very nice on my machine in ultra high detail at 1080p (you need a proper gaming graphics card here by the way), the golfer animation could be doing with being more fluid and the feeling more solid when the ball is struck or impacts the turf. It just feels a little floaty at this point with the golfer, terrain and ball all having a slightly disconnected feel. Additionally, the wind conditions seem to have no effect on the trees or flag; at 50mph the trees move identically to when the wind is at 10mph.On the other hand, the in flight ball physics are awesome and the mouse control "motionswing" mechanic is brilliant and is easily the closest feel to a real golf swing that I've experienced in a PC golf game. This mechanism puts the onus on the tempo and rhythm of your swing rather than just how straight you can move the mouse back and through (anyone remember table edging?). Downswing too fast and the ball is going left, too slow and it's going right, similar to real golf. If you let the pressure get to you and you lose your tempo, you're in trouble, just like real golf.Also, the real time weather and sky conditions make everything feel a lot more realistic and help with immersion.At this point there are no computer opponents and no sort of career mode but these are planned. Additionally, there is no golfer or gear customisation beyond being able to select which 14 clubs you want in your bag.If you are a new starter (or even if you're not), here are my top ten tips for bringing down your scoring and increasing your enjoyment of the game:1) go to options and change the camera to track your shot because it's a static camera by default which is boring2) bring up the map using the button on the top right of the screen to allow for easier aiming3) right clicking in the power circle allows you to change club and select normal or chip shot type4) right clicking again in the power circle allows you to alter the trajectory or add fade/draw bias5) read the instructions and practice with motionswing. It may be tough to start with but it's worth it when it clicks!6) The marker on the putting green has nothing to do with power, only direction. The centre point on the putting power bar is the power needed to reach the hole on a flat green. You need to go past this point if you want to putt uphill7) activate the terrain slope graphics for normal shots as well as putts because the ball being above or below the feet will send the ball left or right respectively8) wind seems to have smaller effects on the ball than in other golf games but once the speed goes above 20mph it starts to have more of an impact9) go into your golfer settings and swap something out for a 64deg wedge. This is easily the most useful club in the bag behind the driver and the putter10) if you want to chat in a multiplayer game, hit enterAs far as multiplayer goes, it is currently based on a peer to peer hosting system with the normal modes of play you would expect and a few unusual ones. Since there is no central server yet you need to ensure you have a fast and stable internet connection if you are going to host a game. Otherwise, ask someone with a better connection to be the host. My experiences have been mostly positive as both host and guest with no disconnections but perhaps I have been lucky with my opponents.From memory I think there are 6 courses currently to choose from and new ones are being added regularly as part of the updates.If you are a fan of golf and you are looking for a proper golf simulator you should buy this game now.If you enjoy golf games in general but want a career mode, customisable equipment and computer opponents, check back in 6-12 months.If you want to pretend you are a superhuman who can drive the ball 400 yards and impart spin with the power of your mind, go play Tiger Woods.

								First, let me say that the gameplay and interface have overall left me with a very positive impression. As regards the gameplay in particular, it is indeed excellent, although even at the easiest setting the shot meter is very unforgiving. A slight miss off the center line, left or right, yields an erring shot in no man's land. So you better hone your reflexes. That caveat notwithstanding, the game is great fun. Kudos to the developers at this stage of development.Now, on the less positive side: the graphics are nice, but a bit disappointing, if we consider that they are roughly on par with the graphics in the game Links 2003. I must say, however, that I am here comparing the best and most recent offerings of this old game, with respect to available courses, and the likes of Shardowlands in Perfect Golf. Still I find that the vegetation, especially the foliage of leafy trees, could and should be better, more polished and photo realistic. I would likewise welcome some flowers in places to add a touch of color and variety to this green fest. Also, even with the antialiasing on, there are still some noticeable jagged edges. Keep in mind that I have the graphical settings at ultra high, with max resolution of 1440 P. In short, I believe there is still work to be done on the part of the developers when it comes to graphics.Clearly, and quite predictably at this stage, there is also a lot of work to be done when It comes to available courses, clubs, and avatars. Furthermore, I would love to see an array of AI opponents of different skill levels for off-line games.I suggest Perfect Parallel include a store in the game to give the option of considerably expanding the content at a reasonable cost. I personally have no issue with financially rewarding the developers (like the competent course designer Mike Jones) for this most promising game. Yes, I am hooked, albeit with some reservations at the present time. I am truly burning with anticipation, thinking of what is to follow for us golf lovers. Let us hope for the best.

Early Access Review
								Have been following this game for a while now.   The game, at this point, will not dazzle you with its graphics (I'm playing all graphics options maxed out, btw), but what it lacks in glitz, it makes up for with the truest golf mechanics and 'feel' that I've yet come across in a golf video game.    I originally started out with the 3-click meter, because that's what I would normally default to after toying around with other games' motion swings (be it the Wiimote, PS controller or mouse).  However, after deciding to give this game's motion swing a try, I'm hooked.    Finally, a game that nails it.  The motion swing is fantastic.   It feels natural and organic, whether on the full swing, chipping or putting.    It's also deep, and difficult (playing with the assists at 'minimal') but with practice, you see improvement as you start to gain feel and muscle memory, just like in real golf.   The game also provides you with numerical feedback (on the driving range practice mode) to illustrate the errors and there is a guide on Steam that explains the numbers.  In short, there are 3 components - tempo, swing path and face contact, all determined by the speed and directions you move your mouse.  The core game is solid.  Once they put some more spit and polish on this and throw in the course forge and other features, it may just be the definitive golf sim that people have been waiting forever for.

								I really like Perfect Golf. It has the look and feel of the PGA Championship PC game that I used to play, but Perfect Golf has the advantage of a strong and growing on-line capability thanks to STEAM. I have just several minor complaints about the game. First, I wish that the wind was more of a factor in the game to make players think a little more about how to shape shots. Clever  players could then hit fades and draws on purpose to hold the ball against the wind, or use the wind more to move around dogleg corners depending on the situation.Second, I don't believe that players are penalized enough when hitting into or out of the trees. I have seen many shots go right through the trees like they were thin air, when in real golf the tree limbs or leaves would have knocked the ball down. Fairway bunker shots also seem a little too easy compared to real golf.Lastly, I suspect that some of the players out there that are using the Motion Plus method to swing the club are using a track or some other kind of aid to move their mouse perfectly each time. It's too much of a coincidence that they have the same shot shape everytime, especially when consistently hitting it with over 100% power. That creates an unfair advantage over those players who use the tri-click method. I recommend that you allow just the tri-click method for on-line play to guarantee that no player has an advantage over any other.

Early Access Review
								In a few words, this is an excellent computer golf game!  It is quite advanced for an early access title.  The game can be very challenging or more relaxing, depending on what level you choose to play at and what aids you select to help your golfing experience.  I think eveyone can find a method to play to make Perfect Golf one of the most enjoyable golf games you've ever played.  I would highly recommend this game to all computer golfers!    What follows in this review is a lengthy discussion of some of the features (not all of them) provided in the game - analogous to the list of options the game provides!I bought Perfect Golf when it first became avialable in Early Access.  I played the Links series of golf, and played a very small bit with the PGA/TW series.  To me, PG is bit more similar to Links than TW games, but it's not a new version of Links.  The game developments over the first 13 months of early access have come reasonably steadily and each one providing new features and bug fixes of the reported issues.  I have complete faith that this will continue for however long early access continues; with the present state of the game, I suspect it won't be much more than a few more months until release (but that is only my guess).The game requires surprisingly (to me) high hardware requirements to get the most detail from the game.  The most important thing is you video card.  You really need to have a dedicated video card; an on-board video card will not deliver the experience that players will want, even at the lowest quality settings of the game.  However, lower end systems and middle-of-the-road systems with dedicated video cards can generally run the game reasonably well.Perfect Golf can be a very difficult golf game - perhaps as difficult as the real game for some.  However, there are many aids that can be employed to make the game more relaxing.  There are currently four options for input methods:- a "traditional" style 3-click swing meter suing the mouse button- game controller with thumbstick on the personal computer- mouse movement, now available in a real-time format, so the golfer swings as you move the mouse- golf simulator hardware (Trackman 3/4, Foresight GC2, SkyTrack)The 3C swing uses a round meter which is pretty familiar to most computer golf players.  I believe the 1.3.9.0 update coming in February 2016 will have an option to make the player avatar move as 3C swing meter moves.  I'm not familiar with the controller methods, so I can't comment on this input method.  The mouse movement method allows you to change the direction of movement from vertical to horizontal as well as the sensitivity to allow for various DPI settings in your mouse configuration as well as various resolution settings for the game itself (4K, HD, VGA, etc.).  The mouse swing can optionally be set as a real-time swing.  I also cannot comment on the simulator input, but from what I've read from those fortunate to have simulator hardware, all very much enjoy Perfect Golf.I really enjoy the challenge of the game using a horizontal mouse swing.  I haven't tried the real-time swing yet, but I definitely will be giving it a go.  I like how you can control the ball movement by making a different path with the mouse, and thus imparting draw/hook spin or fad/slice spin as required for the shot.  The physics of sideslopes, uphill/downhill lies, wind and elevation effects in the game provide the most realistic ball flight I've seen in golf games.  Courses designed in the Course Forge by users wil become avilable for all players very soon.  The previews of the courses as well as a few that have been released by Perfect Parallel with the game so far have been very good.  I suspect there will be many more coming, but I also suspect they will all of be good quality and not something slapped together in a few minutes or hours.  There are many modes of play (stroke/medal play, solo/team match play, and others) as well as the option to play online against other live players from around the world.  There are limimted number of official tournaments at this time, but other web sites, such as the Online Golf Tour or OGT, provide a very good complement to Perfect Golf.  I suspect after the game is release, Perfect Parallel will provide more official tournaments, but it's always good to have optiosn with other tournament providers as well!  OGT will also host user-created courses for free download/addition to the game.One of the few drawbacks in the 1.3.9.0 build of the Perfect Golf may be the lack of a career mode.  Many computer golfers want this, but it won't be provided by Perfect Parallel until after the release of the game.  The ongoing development of the game after release should ensure that a detailed and realistic career mode will be provided, based on the attention to detail and reality that Perfect Parallel have exhibited in the game thus far.  I have no doubt that whatever is eventually provided will be very enjoyable.Perfect Golf is currently only available on the computer (Windows, Mac, Linux), but Perfect Parallel have indicated it will be ported to XBox One and PS4, although no timetable has been provided.  Again, I strongly recommend Perfect Golf for any computer golf fan.  It's a steal for the price and will likely provide many hours of entertainment!!

Early Access Review
								With the advent of the Real Time Swing control interfaces, Perfect Golf has established itself as a major player in the golf game market.  It was already a solid performer with its 3-click and Motion Swing (mouse) swing interfaces. but the all new Real Time Swing - Mouse (RTS-Ml) and Real Time Swing - Controller (RTS-C) broadens the appeal of the game by more dynamically engaging the senses in a live process.Both RTS-C and RTS-M require a sensual mastery over an analog control mechanism that has a reasonable and rewarding learning curve.  There are also 5 levels of difficulty to help you wade into the world of real time swing interfaces at a level suited to any skill set.  I've been a real time swing controller fan since Links 2004 on the original XBox, and Perfect Golf's RTS-C has finally taken a controller swing interface through the portal that Links 2004's opened and added dimensions to its performance that uncannily model the nuances of a golf swing in a manner I wouldn't have ever dreamed would be possible with a controller. I'm a slightly better than average skill player, and I've managed to break par only 3 times in 50+ rounds, using "Hacker" difficulty (the scale runs Beginner, Hacker, Amateur, Pro, Tour Pro) with my XBox 360 wired controller.  Some would say that someone who's used to shooting 62 - 66 in a computer golf game would be frustrated by this.  Au contraire, I find it stimulating to be challenged to fully think out and execute every shot.  A fairway or green in regulation is something you don't take for granted with RTS-C.  What keeps me going is I am seeing a gradual improvement in my game as I become more familiar with the intricately scaled analog interace the game uses.  I'm probably only a few weeks away from stepping up to Amateur!Perfect Golf has so much more to offer besides its cutting edge interface options.  Its course creation suite called "Course Forge" has already given birth to a couple dozen user created courses, many of which are commercial quality.  RobC's Bandon Dunes is as good as any of the stock courses that come with the game.  PG also has a bevy of multiplayer options in its Multiplayer Lobby, in addition to having an ongoing chat room from which you can discuss the game and learn from others.  There's also a facility to support user created tournaments that is proving to be popular with community sites like OnlineGolfTour.net, which hosts a number of Tours and Tournaments of various difficulty and control types, in addition to reviewing and hosting downloadable, user created courses.Keep in mind that Perfect Golf is still in Early Access and is still being refined.  It's highly playable in its current form, but it's also interesting to see the degree of enhancements this game is getting in these final stages.  The developers are also open to user input in these final stages of the game's birth so feel free to sign up at PerfectParallel.com and weigh in with your opinions, experiences, and suggestions.   Whether you're a casual player or a die-hard sim-head, You're not going to find a better value for $19.99!

Early Access Review
								Highly recommended.  A recent update added quite a few community made courses (along with updates to the stock courses in the game) and also added several new swing styles. A wide range of swing styles are available:Traditional 3-click with a power meterMotion Swing with the mouse that has a meter on the screen (your choice of swinging horizontally or vertically)Real Time Swing with the mouse (your choice of swinging horizontally or vertically.  No meter on the screen but the player animation moves in concert with the mouse movement) Real Time Swing with a controller The game can also be played on a home golf simulator.  The motion swings are my personal favorites.  Tempo has a large part in determining the outcome of the shot (as well as swing path and heel/toe hits)  so it's not as simple as straight back/straight through.  A truly wonderful way to play PC golf.  There are also a wide range of difficulty options so you can jump right in and enjoy the game.  The easier levels are a great introduction to the game.  Casual player or just want to have a fun round?  It's here.   The highest levels of difficulty are quite tough but it doesn't feel unfair or gimmicky.  If you can control your swing, you can still score well.  If you're not playing well, it can be a real grind, but  it is so rewarding when you put a good swing on the ball.  A great option for the hardcore sim player. The course designs are beautiful and the ball physics are the best I've seen in a PC golf game.  A wide range of stimp settings are available for the green speeds, several firmness settings for the fairways, and several settings for pin positions.    Currently there are about 33 courses in the game, as well as a large driving range and a short game practice area.  The game is still in Early Access so things are still being worked on.  Things not yet included in the game but are planned for the future:-Career mode-Assortments of clothing/animations/clubheads/balls/shafts etc... -Course building software-More courses-Improved AI for the CPU players-Country clubs and tournamentsThere currently is a REALLY good third party tournament site that hosts weekly tournaments for various skill levels as well as fun ancillary events.  They have an automatic scoring system set up that will keep track of your scores and stats after each round and maintains them on their site.  They also maintain different tours, world rankings, money leaders, ongoing season stats, etc.. and it's free to join.  A very well run tour. http://onlinegolftour.net/index.htmlI'm sure I'm forgetting some things but again, this is a great game.

Early Access Review
								I have been waiting for a golf sim, and the early access of Perfect Golf seems to be headed in the right direction. Obviously, with an early access, there are things that are needed and things that are fine as is. So far, I can say confidently that the heart is beating in this game. Visually it's appealing and the game-play engine itself is a good start. Some of the issues at this point, I hesitate to mention, again because I suspect every feature and tweak I would like to see has been accounted for by the developers and they are working on it. That being said: The menus need work and making changes to the settings on the fly is clunky. The types of shots are limited at the moment and needs attention, as does the power meter and putting helpers. Right now, they don't really make much sense and seem arbitrary. There's no way to punch shots through or accurately alter spin the way the real game allows. The power meters and putting grids also are somewhat of a mystery and don't seem to be designed to let the player really know exact measurements. This may be on purpose, but still this is a sim and not real life, so we need some way to benchmark our swings and fades, etc... It needs a player history system so I can go back and review my previous rounds, and of course, it needs more courses. I hope most of all, the developers are going to be able to make a deal with the PGA for rights to their courses and tournament play, but even if it remains simply a non-PGA golf simulation, that's fine on its own. If you want to learn the game and progress without getting bored, I think this will be a good title someday. I hope it is sooner than later.added: May 5, 2016: Now that the supposed general release has been pushed out, I felt I need to comment further on this game. As I said in my earlier review, the heart of a good game was there, and I was hoping Perfect Parrellel was working hard on the serious issues in the engine. Apparently, they are working harder on the marketing and getting Jack Nicklaus to put his name on a game that is FAR, FAR from finished. I'm wondering if the makers of this game couldn't care less about the gamers in Steam and are more interested in the Golf Simulators out there than can use this software. Because right now, us gamers are getting no love from the game. A few points for the developers, which I hope read this: ...The putting mechinism is simply awful. Damn near unplayable. It's swing mechanics are inconsistent and clunky. There is no context to the power of the swing and they give little to no credible way to read the greens. It needs serious re-tooling before this game can be considered top notch. ...there is no way to craft shots and the chipping and pitching is abysmal and inconsitent. You'll never hit the same shot twice in the same conditions. ...the swing meter, which is the only way most gamers are going to play this game, is baffling and inconsistent. it gives no power context either but even if it did, you can never re-create shots no matter how hard you try. I'm holding out hope this will improve, but if this is now considered a released game, I'm not holding my breath that major changes to the engine are coming.updated: June 17...a few of the patches and fixes are helping on some of the issues I pointed out in May. Putting seems to have normalized somewhat. It's getting better about giving enough clues to read a green. Still, I think the grid needs to be smaller squares and the BLI is a little clunky, but better. ...still though, chipping and pitching are so frustrating. Practice is one thing, but inconsistency in the UI and the game engine is something else. Pitching and chipping still is a nightmare of randomness. Random in that you never ever know how your chip or pitch is going to react in any situation. it's impossible to recreate a shot that has the same variables and the engine will flatout fail you by over shooting or undershooting even though the power, lie and variables might be the same. NEEDS ATTENTION NOW....crafting shots is still a major problem. the shot maker function just doesn't work for lowering or raising your trajectory. It works left and right, but not up and down. ...still worth it, as this is a simulation and not an arcade, ,and as long as they don't morph into a pay to win model, I will continue to recommend it.

												Jack Nicklaus Perfect Golf is what you play if you're looking for a realistic and challenging golf sim. This is the real deal.The game can be as hard as you want it to be. Want to go easy on a flat green course using 3 point click on Beginner? Go for it. After a while, you'll birdie too often and want more of a challenge. No problem. There's Hacker, Amateur, Tour, and Tour Pro that'll challenge you further. These higher difficulties make swing timings more precise, resulting in shots more prone to shank if you're off just a bit. At the highest levels, you won't even be told the wind speed or direction and will have to rely on visual cues like the flag's movement. This says nothing of additional round settings like wind speeds (which can be set to weather forecasts), pin placements, green firmness, etc. You'll botch plenty of shots at first until you practice to get your swing down while you learn to master both courses and conditions. Just like in real golf.Beyond that, there are different swing styles that change ball striking experience. Want to feel like you're actually swinging something on your PC without a gamepad? Motion Swing allows you to use your mouse as a club to swing. You'll have to literally swing back and forward both straight and within a backswing-to-forwardswing time frame ratio in order to hit your shot straight. If you have a controller, you can use joysticks. This is a game with a great deal of depth and multiplayer replayability with a learning curve as steep as you make it. Still, the game launched a bit prematurely. The multiplayer lobby is quirky, at best; dysfunctional, at worst. Computer opponents are wildly inconsistent, too, so to play a decent opponent, you'll have to put up with the lobby's quirkiness or practice on your own.In spite of all of this, if you're pleased enough with the gameplay, you'll be patient in waiting for patches to remedy the game's weaknesses.There are negative reviews about season passes that are misinformed. These passes are for additional equipment you can buy to actually hit golf balls into a net and track their flight in-game, which seems like a pretty dang cool add-on if you ask me. The developers are in no way forcing customers to pay for the base game and a season pass to play for a year.The store also offers additional courses to purchase—currently Bethesda for $4.99. There is unwarranted outcry about this as well because the game comes bundled with plenty of courses to keep the gameplay varied enough for a good while—14 full courses if my count is right, and 2 practice ranges. Offering additional DLC content to the core game is exactly what a lot of developers do these days. It's not in the base game, so therefore, you pay more for it. Sounds fair enough.All in all, the strengths far outweigh the weaknesses. I do hope the developers continue to flesh out the kinks, but they've managed to produce a very solid game with gameplay that'll keep you coming back for more if the sort of golf sim you're looking for is both realistic and increasingly challenging. These two strengths make the game that much more rewarding and fun when you do get a handle on things and are able to be competitive against others in multiplayer matches.

												As a very long term user of the Links Golf Game I and many others have had to wait an age for a worthy replacement to appear.  There are many Golf sims and I have tried them all but following Microsofts decicion to no longer support Links after 2003 left many Golf players frustrated.  Links did however have an excellent course designer and they are lots of great designers out there who continued to support the game and gave the community loads of great courses to play.Two of the finest designers then started Perfect Parallel with the eventual aim of releasing this game.  I joined the kickstarter campaign and was thrilled when the game got the Green Light from Steam.  When the game finally arrived I was very dissapointed because the game looked great but didn't play very well.The engine lagged badly so I went back to Links I even made sure that I updated my graphics card to be compatible with Links when I upgraded my computer.  A year os so further on I have returned to this game and I can safetly say that this is a worthy successor to Links.The graphics are beautiful the game supports lots of swing types and you can impliment real time weather for most locations all over the world but these are just small details what's important is how the game plays.  A year on the game now plays flawlessly so even if you only like the occasional casual game of golf this is as goods as it gets.  Those serious about their armchair golf will already have it. One of the coolest  things about these games is the course designer.  The designer that came with Links was fit for purpose but course design was involved and time consuming to say the least.The designer for this game called Course Forge is simpler and more intuitive to use but is not yet available but is due imminently.There are already plenty of cources to download other than those that come with the game from the link on the introduction page from designers that have been given early access and the standards are awesome.  These are now being released at a rate of about 5 a month and this will accelerate once the Course Forge is availanle for all. It would be amazing to see further cources particularly some of the best designs from the Links series.  Mike Jones one of Links premier designers really needs to make the rest of his cources available for Perfect Golf time permitting.How about it Mike?  Who knows once the CF is ready I might just add 1 or 2 designs of my own. In the meantime I'm off to play the remaining cources that I've downloaded in rainy old Blighty.  Highly recommended.

												This game has been more roller coaster than golf sometimes; the devs have made a lot of changes over the development of this game and they listened a lot to the players, and opening up course design was interesting, and it remians a golf simulator to follow. It does keep changing, sometimes in little ways sometimes in surprising ways. After the last update, so much changed that I've stopped playing pretty much. It used to be fun. Tweak tweaks - now it's not fun; it's work and it has changes that I just cannot figure out how to adjust, why they made it, and how can I get back an older version? Putting is a real problem at the time I write this review, and it never was this much of an issue before. So I'm pretty tired of trying to re-learn this game every release. However, those releases also made some great improvements both visual and functional, and their active involvement has brought the game along nicely. (One reviewer seem to think there was no "dev'elopment; I disagree: this game has one of the most devoted dev teams around.It has a lot of courses, many really good free ones; the basics are all there, it has several levels of play, all of which are too tough for this old guy, and enough free presonalization to make your game look good. They have big plans in the golf world and while some of the bells and whistles aren't there (never missed the crowd noise anyways, no fancy locker rooms to acess data, etc.) there's a lot there, almost everything can be controlled with sliders, it supports really nice graphics, There's an active lobby, several tournaments both 'official' and open, but all use levels of play above the starter level, so your controls may look different, and you may want to learn the higher levels of controls; me I have trouble enough on hacker, or whatever the lowest is. The game is very good at recovery, if you lose connections, or in multi-player, you have a good chance of picking up right where you left off. There's an active community base and an active forum, and an at-times chatty lobby.Overall it is a very well-designed (and still being designed) game with great emersion, simple to learn, hard to master; lots of features and options and seems to have a robust future. Now let's all just get through 2017!
